title: 110_hr3678
content: The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes to extend until 2014. States that currently tax internet access are grandfathered in. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of "Internet access" for subsections (a) and (b) effective as of November 1, 2003. The Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act (Public Law 108-435) exempts certain taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008, if they were imposed on telecommunications services inconsistent with the Act before July 1, 2007, or are subject to ongoing litigation. The Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act exempts certain taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008, if they were imposed on telecommunications services inconsistently before July 1, 2007, or are part of ongoing litigation. No legislative construction inference can be drawn from this subsection for any period before June 30, 2008. The Internet Tax Nondiscrimination Act exempts certain taxes on Internet access until June 30, 2008, subject to exceptions in subparagraphs (A) and (B) of paragraph (2). SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of Internet access as a service enabling users to connect to the Internet for content and services. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services that enable users to access content, information, or services over the Internet. This encompasses services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage. It does not include voice, audio, or video programming. The definition of Internet access under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage. It does not include voice, audio, or video programming, or other products and services that utilize Internet protocol and for which there is a charge. The definition of telecommunications under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes telecommunications services as defined in the Communications Act of 1934 and communications services as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'tax on Internet access' does not include a State tax on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of a business, as specified by State law. The tax must have been enacted between June 20, 2005, and November 1, 2007, or between January 1, 1932, and January 1, 1936 for a State business tax. It should replace a modified value-added tax or a tax on net income, capital stock, or net worth. The tax must be broad and imposed on various business activities. The tax imposed should be broad and not discriminatory towards providers of communication services, Internet access, or telecommunications. The state can modify taxes on business activities after November 1, 2007, as long as it doesn't significantly limit the range of taxed activities. No legislative construction can be inferred from this regarding taxes before November. The state can modify taxes on business activities after November 1, 2007, without significantly limiting the range of taxed activities. No legislative construction can be inferred from this regarding taxes before November. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to replace "telecommunications services" with "telecommunications" and expand the definition to include enabling users to access content on the Internet. Additionally, a section related to voice services is removed from the Act. SEC. 6. SUNSET OF GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS. This section states that certain exceptions to the Internet Tax Freedom Act will not apply to states that have repealed taxes on Internet access more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective from November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, except as specified in section 1104 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
